title: The Psychology of Listicles

multiple-choice.question: What is a listicle?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of article that includes a combination of writing and images.

options.label: B
options.text: A list of items or information presented in a concise manner.

multiple-choice.question: Why are listicles popular?

options.label: A
options.text: They are easy to understand and allow people to quickly process information.

options.label: B
options.text: They are a new form of entertainment on the internet.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a way to curate information and help people make sense of a large amount of data.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a way to count and categorize information.

multiple-choice.question: What is cognitive fluency?

options.label: A
options.text: A measure of how easy it is to think about something.

options.label: B
options.text: A measure of how hard it is to think about something.

options.label: C
options.text: A measure of how much information a person can process.

options.label: D
options.text: A measure of how much a person remembers.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when people are exposed to information that is easy to process?

options.label: A
options.text: They are less likely to remember it.

options.label: B
options.text: They are more likely to judge it as true.

options.label: C
options.text: They are less likely to twitch their muscles into a little subconscious smile.

options.label: D
options.text: They are less likely to be satisfied.

multiple-choice.question: Why are listicles appealing?

options.label: A
options.text: They are easy to understand and allow people to quickly process information.

options.label: B
options.text: They are a new form of entertainment on the internet.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a way to curate information and help people make sense of a large amount of data.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a way to count and categorize information.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a listicle?

options.label: A
options.text: To educate people about a particular topic.

options.label: B
options.text: To entertain people and provide a quick and easy way to process information.

options.label: D
options.text: To make people remember specific facts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the working memory, according to Peter Dolittle?

options.label: B
options.text: The size of a small car.

options.label: C
options.text: The size of a large house.

options.label: D
options.text: The size of a football field.

multiple-choice.question: How many things do people tend to remember for 10-20 seconds unless they do something with it?
What happens to any bite of information that is not processed or remembered?

options.label: A
options.text: It is stored in long-term memory.

options.label: C
options.text: It is processed and used for future reference.

options.label: D
options.text: It is in one ear and out the other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the opinion of the author about listicles as pieces of education?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a great way to learn new things.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not a good way to learn new things.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a neutral way to learn new things.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a bad way to learn new things.

title: How many verb tenses are there in English? - Anna Ananichuk

multiple-choice.question: What is grammatical tense?

options.label: A
options.text: A way to describe time periods explicitly.

options.label: B
options.text: A way languages talk about time without explicitly naming time periods.

options.label: C
options.text: A way to describe the speaker's emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: A way to describe the location of an action.

multiple-choice.question: How many different kinds of aspect are there in a language like English?
What is the continuous or progressive aspect?

options.label: B
options.text: Describes actions that are ongoing at the time of reference.

options.label: D
options.text: Describes actions that are not specified as continuous or discrete.

multiple-choice.question: What is the perfect aspect?

options.label: A
options.text: Describes actions that are ongoing at the time of reference.

options.label: D
options.text: Describes actions that are not specified as continuous or discrete.

multiple-choice.question: How many different tenses are there in English, including aspects?
What is the future perfect progressive aspect?

options.label: A
options.text: A combination of the future and perfect aspects.

options.label: B
options.text: A combination of the future and continuous aspects.

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of the future and simple aspects.

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of the past and perfect aspects.

multiple-choice.question: What does the simple aspect describe?

options.label: A
options.text: Actions that are ongoing at the time of reference.

options.label: C
options.text: Actions that are not specified as continuous or discrete.

multiple-choice.question: Which language is mentioned as having no verb tenses at all, only aspect?
What do languages like Yagwa do with the past tense?

options.label: A
options.text: They split it into multiple degrees, like whether something happened hours, weeks, or years ago.

options.label: B
options.text: They describe and divide time differently.

options.label: C
options.text: They take a similar approach to English.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point of aspects in a language?

options.label: B
options.text: To describe the location of an action.

options.label: C
options.text: To tell you as of a specific moment the status of the action.

options.label: D
options.text: To describe the time period of an action.

title: Does my dog know what I'm thinking?

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: That emotions are not important for understanding human behavior.

title: What happens during a stroke? - Vaibhav Goswami

multiple-choice.question: What is the frequency of strokes in the world?

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To check for signs of a stroke

title: Why do mirrors flip horizontally (but not vertically)?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why mirrors appear to flip things horizontally but not vertically?

options.label: A
options.text: The mirror reflects the image in the x direction but not the y direction.

options.label: B
options.text: The mirror reflects the image in the z direction, causing a horizontal flip.

options.label: C
options.text: The mirror reflects the image in the y direction but not the x direction.

options.label: D
options.text: The mirror reflects the image in the x direction and the y direction equally.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the word "food" appear to be flipped horizontally when viewed in a mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the mirror is reflecting the image in the x direction.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: Because the word is being viewed from a different angle.

options.text: Because mirrors reflect the image in the z direction.

options.label: A

options.text: Because mirrors reflect the image in the z direction.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we are looking at our reflection from a different angle.

options.label: A
options.text: Because most words we see in the mirror are on t-shirts and we don't think of them as horizontally flipped.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because mirrors reflect the image in the x direction.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Because mirrors reflect the image in the x direction.

options.label: C
options.text: Because mirrors reflect the image in the z direction.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we are looking at our reflection from a different angle.

options.label: A
options.text: Because the mirror reflects the image in the x direction but not the y direction.

options.text: Because the mirror reflects the image in the z direction, causing a horizontal flip.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the mirror reflects the image in the y direction but not the x direction.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mirror reflects the image in the x direction and the y direction equally.

title: Ugly History: The 1937 Haitian Massacre - Edward Paulino

options.label: C

options.text: The Dominican Republic's declaration of independence in 1844

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To punish Haitians for their role in the 1804 slave revolt

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: Can you solve the dark coin riddle? - Lisa Winer

multiple-choice.question: What is the task that the traveler has to complete in order to leave the dungeon with the stash of ancient Stygian coins?

options.label: A
options.text: To find the legendary dungeon and collect the coins.

options.label: B
options.text: To separate the coins into two piles with the same number of coins facing silver side up.

options.label: C
options.text: To defeat the eccentric wizard in a battle.

options.label: D
options.text: To solve a puzzle and answer a riddle.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the traveler need to separate the coins into two piles with the same number of coins facing silver side up?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the wizard wants to see if the traveler can count.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the traveler needs to find a way to flip the coins over.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the number of silver-facing coins in each pile needs to be the same.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the traveler wants to win a prize.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the traveler moves aside 20 coins and flips each one of them over?

options.text: The number of silver-facing coins in the original pile increases.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of gold-facing coins in the new pile increases.

options.label: C
options.text: The number of silver-facing coins in the new pile with the 20 coins that were moved increases.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of gold-facing coins in the original pile increases.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason behind the traveler's solution of moving aside 20 coins and flipping each one of them over?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the traveler wants to make sure the number of silver-facing coins is the same in each pile.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the traveler knows that the number of gold-facing coins will be 20 minus the number of silver-facing coins in the new pile.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the traveler is trying to make the problem more difficult.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the traveler wants to see how many coins are facing silver side up.

multiple-choice.question: What concept is used to explain why the traveler's solution works?
What is the total number of coins in the new pile when the traveler moves aside 20 coins and flips each one of them over?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of silver-facing coins in the new pile increases.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of gold-facing coins in the new pile becomes the same as the number of silver-facing coins in the original pile.

options.label: C
options.text: The number of gold-facing coins in the new pile decreases.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of silver-facing coins in the new pile decreases.

title: What are mini brains? - Madeline Lancaster

title: Could we cure aging during your lifetime?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of the medical community, according to the speaker?

options.text: That stem cells are the only solution to aging

title: Why you should define your fears instead of your goals

options.text: He has only experienced minor depressive episodes.

options.label: D
options.text: He has only experienced depression since he was a teenager.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the Stoic philosophy that the author has found helpful in managing his depression and making decisions?    - A: Stoicism
What is the name of the exercise that the author created to help him manage his fears and make decisions?    - A: Fear-setting
What is the purpose of the "Prevent" column in the fear-setting exercise?    - A: To write down the worst-case scenarios that could happen if the author takes a particular action.

options.label: B
options.text: To write down the benefits of taking a particular action.

options.label: C
options.text: To write down the steps the author can take to prevent the worst-case scenarios from happening.

options.label: D
options.text: To write down the cost of inaction.

multiple-choice.question: Who is Jerzy Gregorek, and what is his relationship to the author?    - A: Jerzy Gregorek is a four-time world champion in Olympic weightlifting and a close friend of the author.

options.label: B

multiple-choice.question: What is Jerzy Gregorek's mantra, and what does it mean?    - A: "Easy choices, hard life. Hard choices, easy life."

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: "Life is easy when you make hard choices."

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: To make hard choices and solve problems.

options.label: C
options.text: To focus on defining their goals rather than their fears.

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on their fears rather than their goals.

What is the author's purpose in sharing his story and the story of Jerzy Gregorek?    - A: To entertain the audience.

options.label: B
options.text: To educate the audience about Stoicism.

options.label: C
options.text: To inspire the audience to make hard choices and solve problems.

options.label: D
options.text: To motivate the audience to focus on their goals rather than their fears.

title: Who's at risk for colon cancer? - Amit H. Sachdev and Frank G. Gress

options.label: D

options.text: To prevent the spread of cancer

options.label: C
options.text: To detect and remove offending polyps before they can cause cancer

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: How to manage your time more effectively (according to machines) - Brian Christian

options.label: D
options.text: It was destroyed in a meteor shower.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the algorithm that is described as a problem in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To replace it with a full ranking of all tasks.

options.label: B
options.text: To use a limited number of priority "buckets."

options.label: C
options.text: To use a random number generator to decide which task to do next.

options.label: D
options.text: To use a timer to decide which task to do next.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no tradeoff between productivity and responsiveness.

multiple-choice.question: What is the solution to the problem of minimizing context switches and being responsive at the same time?

options.label: C
options.text: To use a timer to decide which task to do next.

options.label: D
options.text: To use a random number generator to decide which task to do next.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the idea in computer science that involves grouping interruptions together based on how long they can afford to wait?

options.label: B
options.text: It had no effect on battery life.

options.label: C
options.text: It triggered a massive improvement in laptop battery life.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Computers never get interrupted, unlike humans.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What is the tragedy of the commons? - Nicholas Amendolare

multiple-choice.question: What is the key feature of a tragedy of the commons?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a way for individuals to share resources equally.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows individuals to benefit themselves while spreading out any negative effects across the larger population.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a problem that only affects small groups of people.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a concept that was first described by Garrett Hardin.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the pamphlet by economist William Forster Lloyd in 1833 that first described the concept of the tragedy of the commons?

options.label: B
options.text: "The Overgrazing of Cattle on Village Common Areas"

multiple-choice.question: According to Garrett Hardin, what is the result of individuals acting in their own self-interest when a tragedy of the commons occurs?

options.label: A
options.text: The common good is protected and preserved.

options.label: B
options.text: The problem is solved and the resource is replenished.

options.label: C
options.text: The problem is exacerbated and the resource is depleted.

options.label: D
options.text: The issue is ignored and the problem goes away.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a tragedy of the commons in the real world, as described by Garrett Hardin?

options.label: A
options.text: The overuse of antibiotics has led to the evolution of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

options.label: B
options.text: The overfishing of oceans has led to the depletion of fish populations.

options.label: C
options.text: The overgrazing of cattle has led to the depletion of grasslands.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main conclusion that Garrett Hardin draws from the concept of the tragedy of the commons?

options.label: A
options.text: Individuals should always act in their own self-interest.

options.label: B
options.text: The common good is more important than individual interests.

options.label: C
options.text: Humans are capable of solving problems and saving themselves from their own individual impulses.

options.label: D
options.text: The tragedy of the commons is a problem that can only be solved through government intervention.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the classic problem that Garrett Hardin used to describe the concept of the tragedy of the commons?
According to the transcript, what is the main reason why the fish population in the pond is depleted when individuals act in their own self-interest?

options.label: B
options.text: Because the fish are not reproducing fast enough.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the individuals are taking more fish than they need.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the individuals are not taking enough fish.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a social contract that humans have formed to save themselves from their own individual impulses?

options.label: B
options.text: Making communal agreements and passing laws.

multiple-choice.question: According to Garrett Hardin, what is the ultimate solution to the tragedy of the commons?

options.label: C
options.text: Individuals acting in their own self-interest.

options.label: D
options.text: Humans forming social contracts and making communal agreements.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main lesson that Garrett Hardin draws from the concept of the tragedy of the commons?

options.label: A
options.text: When the tragedy of the commons applies, what's good for all of us is good for each of us.

options.label: B
options.text: When the tragedy of the commons applies, what's good for each of us is good for all of us.

options.label: C
options.text: When the tragedy of the commons applies, individuals should act in their own self-interest.

options.label: D
options.text: When the tragedy of the commons applies, the common good is more important than individual interests.

title: How often should you get a flu shot? - Melvin Sanicas

multiple-choice.question: Why do we need a new flu vaccine every year?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the flu virus has a single subtype.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the flu virus mutates slowly.

options.label: C
options.text: Because there are over 100 subtypes of the influenza virus and the ones in circulation change from season to season.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the flu vaccine is not effective.

multiple-choice.question: What makes the flu's genetic code unique?

options.label: B
options.text: It has a slow mutation rate.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows the flu virus to mutate more quickly than many other viruses.

multiple-choice.question: How does the flu virus replicate?

options.label: A
options.text: By expelling its genetic material and making its way to the nucleus.

options.label: B
options.text: By replicating its genetic material in the cytoplasm.

options.label: C
options.text: By using a host cell's machinery to replicate viral genes.

options.label: D
options.text: By releasing new viruses from the cell.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem with RNA viruses like the flu?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a slow mutation rate.

options.label: C
options.text: They can mutate more quickly and have a higher error rate.

multiple-choice.question: How do vaccines work against the flu?

options.label: A
options.text: By recognizing and attacking the virus directly.

options.label: B
options.text: By producing antibodies that match the antigens on the surface of the virus.

options.label: D
options.text: By preventing the virus from entering the cell.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to create a universal flu vaccine?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the flu virus has a single subtype.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the flu virus mutates slowly.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the flu virus has over 100 subtypes and can mutate quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the flu vaccine is not effective.

multiple-choice.question: What is herd immunity?

options.label: A
options.text: A measure of how effective a vaccine is.

options.label: B
options.text: A way to prevent the spread of the flu.

options.label: C
options.text: A way to protect people who are not medically eligible for the shot.

options.label: D
options.text: A way to prevent the flu from spreading to other people.

multiple-choice.question: What is the World Health Organization's role in creating the flu vaccine?

options.label: B
options.text: To collect data on which strains are circulating and how much they have mutated.

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze the data and determine which strains to include in the vaccine.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a shot and an inhaled vaccine?

options.label: A
options.text: The shot contains a weakened live virus, while the inhaled vaccine contains an inactivated virus.

options.label: B
options.text: The shot contains an inactivated virus, while the inhaled vaccine contains a weakened live virus.

options.label: C
options.text: The shot is more effective than the inhaled vaccine.

options.label: D
options.text: The shot is less effective than the inhaled vaccine.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it safe to get the flu shot?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it contains a weakened live virus.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it contains an inactivated virus that is not capable of making you sick.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has a high error rate.

title: Why incompetent people think they're amazing - David Dunning

options.label: B
options.text: They are more aware of their weaknesses

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: They make fewer mistakes and reach better decisions

options.label: C
options.text: They assume that everyone else is knowledgeable, too

options.label: D
options.text: They become more aware of their weaknesses

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: They are more confident in their abilities

options.label: B
options.text: They are more aware of their weaknesses

options.label: C
options.text: They have a moderate amount of experience or expertise

options.label: D
options.text: They have a strong grasp of the rules of debate

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of people being caught in a bubble of inaccurate self-perception?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more confident in their abilities

options.label: B
options.text: They make fewer mistakes and reach better decisions

options.label: C
options.text: They suffer a double curse of making mistakes and being unable to recognize their errors

options.label: D
options.text: They are unable to recognize their own faults

title: Can you solve the egg drop riddle? - Yossi Elran

multiple-choice.question: The Fabergé Egg Museum has a 100-story building with a single egg displayed on each floor. What is the least number of tries it would take to guarantee that the thief finds the right floor?

options.label: B
options.text: To test the security of the museum

options.label: C
options.text: To find the highest floor at which an egg will survive the fall without breaking

multiple-choice.question: If the thief only had one replica egg, how many tries could it take to find the right floor?
What is the advantage of using an additional replica egg?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the thief to steal more eggs

options.label: B
options.text: It gives the thief a better option to narrow down the range where the critical floor can be found

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the heist more difficult

options.label: D
options.text: It is not relevant to the heist

multiple-choice.question: What is the optimal interval size for dropping the first egg to minimize the number of tries?
What is the main goal when dividing the building into sections?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the heist more difficult

options.label: B
options.text: To find the highest floor at which an egg will survive the fall without breaking

options.label: C
options.text: To divide the building into sections where no matter which floor is correct, it takes up to the same number of throws to find it

multiple-choice.question: What is the equation that can help solve for the first floor we need to start with in the 100 floor building?
What is the solution to the equation n(n+1) = 100?
How many drops will the thief make if she starts on the 14th floor, moving up to the 27th, the 39th, and so on?
What is the main takeaway from the problem?

options.label: A
options.text: The thief can steal as many eggs as she wants

options.label: B
options.text: The thief can find the right floor with a minimum number of tries

options.label: C
options.text: The thief can make the heist more difficult

options.label: D
